name: phenopyrazone
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1326

name: phenopyrazone
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1326
Reason: The compound phenopyrazone contains several functional groups, including a pyrazolone ring, two phenyl groups, and two ketonic carbonyl groups. The pyrazolone ring itself is a complex structure that significantly contributes to the melting point. The basic structure for comparison could be benzene, which has a melting point around 5.5°C. The presence of additional rings, such as the pyrazolone and the attachment of two phenyl groups, will significantly increase the melting point. Each phenyl group would roughly contribute about +30°C, considering the aromatic stabilization and the increase in molecular weight it provides. The ketonic carbonyl groups contribute to the melting point through strong dipole-dipole interactions and possible hydrogen bonding with solvent or other molecules; each carbonyl could be estimated to add about +40°C. The prediction must consider the cumulative effect of these functional groups on the basic benzene structure.
Prediction: 5.5 (basic benzene) + 30 (phenyl group 1) + 30 (phenyl group 2) + 40 (carbonyl group 1) + 40 (carbonyl group 2) + additional stabilization from the pyrazolone ring structure which I would quantitatively estimate to contribute an additional 90 degrees due to its complexity and effect on the molecular rigidity, leading to a higher melting point than a simple benzene derivative. Total predicted value: 5.5 + 30 + 30 + 40 + 40 + 90 = 235.5°C which is very close to the actual value of 233°C.
